question: She speaks English _____ than her brother.
description: Adverbs of manner like 'fluently' describe how an action is done. Here, we compare two people, so we use the comparative form 'more fluently'.

question: I have _____ finished the project, just a few more tasks are left.
description: 'Almost' is an adverb of degree that means nearly. It is used to indicate that something is very close to being completed.

question: He can _____ speak French; he only knows a few words.
description: 'Hardly' is an adverb of degree that expresses a very limited extent, meaning 'barely' or 'almost not'.

question: She goes to the gym _____ every day.
description: 'Almost' in this context is an adverb of frequency, meaning she attends nearly every day but not always.

question: The report is _____ finished, we just need to proofread it.
description: 'Nearly' is an adverb of degree meaning 'almost', used to show that the action is close to completion.

question: They arrived _____ late and missed the first act.
description: 'Too' is an adverb of degree that indicates excess, in this case, indicating they were excessively late.

question: She answered the question _____, showing she understood it well.
description: 'Quickly' is the correct adverb of manner to describe how the action of answering was performed.

question: He _____ goes to the library, only when he has exams.
description: 'Rarely' is an adverb of frequency that means not often, which fits the context where he visits only during exams.

question: I will finish this work _____ tomorrow.
description: 'By' is an adverb of time indicating a deadline, meaning 'before or at the latest time'.

question: He spoke _____ in the meeting, despite being nervous.
description: 'Confidently' is an adverb of manner that describes how he spoke, modifying the verb 'spoke'.

question: She has _____ finished her degree, just her thesis is pending.
description: 'Almost' is an adverb of degree used here to express that only a small part of the work remains.

question: The train will arrive _____ than expected, due to the weather.
description: 'Later' is a comparative adverb of time used to indicate that the arrival will be after the expected time.

question: We will _____ discuss this topic tomorrow.
description: 'Surely' is an adverb of expectation indicating confidence that the action will happen in the future.

question: He behaves _____ in class, which annoys the teacher.
description: 'Badly' is an adverb of manner that modifies the verb 'behaves' to describe how he behaves.

question: She _____ does her homework before dinner.
description: 'Usually' is an adverb of frequency indicating that she regularly does her homework before dinner.

question: He _____ finished his meal, only a few bites were left.
description: 'Almost' is an adverb of degree used to indicate something is nearly complete.

question: Sheâ€™s been working _____ hard for the past few weeks.
description: 'Extremely' is an adverb of degree that intensifies the adjective 'hard' to emphasize how hard she has been working.

question: They finished the project _____ time for the presentation.
description: 'In time' is an idiomatic expression that means finishing before a particular time or deadline.

question: She will _____ be here for the meeting.
description: 'Certainly' is an adverb of expectation, expressing confidence or surety that she will attend.

question: The performance was _____ good that the audience gave a standing ovation.
description: 'So' is an adverb of degree used to intensify an adjective and often followed by a result, as in 'so good that...'.

question: She _____ ever visits her grandparents, though they live nearby.
description: 'Rarely' is an adverb of frequency meaning 'not often', appropriate in the context of infrequent visits.

question: The children are playing _____ the park.
description: 'In' is an adverb of place used when something happens inside a space, such as 'in the park'.

question: I will _____ be able to finish this task without your help.
description: 'Hardly' is an adverb of degree meaning 'barely' or 'almost not', implying the difficulty of finishing alone.

question: She runs _____ than anyone else on the team.
description: 'More quickly' is the comparative form of the adverb 'quickly', used to compare her speed with others.

question: The news is _____ good to be true.
description: 'Too' is an adverb of degree used to indicate excess, meaning the news is excessively good.

question: He has _____ completed his project, just a few changes are left.
description: 'Nearly' is an adverb of degree meaning 'almost', suitable when only minor adjustments are left.

question: She walked _____ to avoid making any noise.
description: 'Silently' is the adverb of manner modifying 'walked', describing how she performed the action.

question: We _____ go to the movies on weekends.
description: 'Usually' is an adverb of frequency indicating that going to the movies is a common activity on weekends.

question: She finished the race _____ of all the participants.
description: 'Most quickly' is the superlative form of the adverb 'quickly', used to compare her with all other participants.

question: The teacher spoke _____, ensuring everyone understood the instructions.
description: 'Clearly' is an adverb of manner that modifies the verb 'spoke', describing how the teacher communicated.
